awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Empowering Software Engineering with Eye Tracking
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research project is to advance knowledge of developer activity by conducting empirical studies on large software systems using an eye tracker. Most eye tracking studies done in software engineering use small snippets of software artifacts such as source code that are shown as images or text. With software artifacts being hundreds of lines long, doing realistic studies using a variety of software artifacts is not practical. To address this problem, this research will develop a robust infrastructure that enables implicit eye tracking within the working environment of the developer thereby supporting inherent scrolling on large files and automating the linking of eye gaze to artifact elements looked at. This infrastructure will advance the state of the art in conducting eye tracking studies in software engineering.

The proposed research will lead to inventing, evaluating, and applying innovative methods and tools that use developer eye gaze to support the developer in software engineering tasks such as code summarization, code recommendations, and software traceability. Additional activities that crosscut these three main directions are related to using eye tracking as a benchmark and standardizing visual effort metrics. The broader impacts of this work include developing educational course content, increased mentoring of underrepresented undergraduate student groups, developing open source software, producing large eye tracking datasets, and collaborating with industry for assessment and validation of the proposed research. Educational activities also include a strong K-12 outreach program to encourage students to pursue a career in computing.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The project is aimed at advancing our knowledge of developer activity by conducting empirical studies using an eye tracker, which in turn will lead to inventing, evaluating, and applying innovative methods and tools that use developer eye gaze to support the developer in software engineering tasks.. In order to support these three directions of research, one of the goals is to run realistic empirical studies using an eye tracker both in the lab and in the field. In addition to conducting empirical studies, another goal is to contribute to the iTrace infrastructure and make it a usable tool for the community.  The educational and outreach goals are to motivate K-12 students to pursue STEM using projects based on eye tracking technology, involving graduate and undergraduate students in research, and advancing research opportunities for undergraduates from underrepresented groups.  

Intellectual Merit

The project supported the design and analysis of approximately 27 studies since 2016 in the field of program comprehension, code review, defect detection, expertise prediction, code readability, traceability, and productivity. Some of the studies were completely new studies, others were reanalysis of older data with a new objective. Each study brings forth unique insights about how eye tracking, when used in realistic contexts, can indeed tell us a different story compared to toy-like settings. A great example of this is how results change when we expose developers to the entire system for a summarization task vs. just a small snippet of code. Code readability studies show how certain rules such as minimize nesting to improve readability do indeed have an effect on task performance. Our recent work shows how we can model human attention from eye movements to support neural source code summarization. We also show how programming language and task play a role in how computer science students learn.

In addition to studies done, several iTrace architecture papers describing how to use the system were released to help support the community use and extend it. iTrace is now a modular system with support for VSCode (a hacked version due to plugin limitations), Visual Studio, Atom, and Eclipse. It also has a post-processing toolkit for mapping gaze to source code and generating fixations.  A screen recording plugin was also recently released. iTrace directly enables new research in several software engineering research areas.  The contributions of this project are a forward step towards making eye tracking a novel method in identifying software developer’s fine-grained navigation and viewing behavior while they work on realistic software tasks.

Broader Impacts

With eye-tracking empirical studies at its core, the findings from the empirical studies directly impact various software engineering tasks such as code summarization, code readability, defect detection, code review and more. With recorded eye gaze sessions, we are able to see all the places that the developer looked to get to the answer and not just the final answer. The education component of this proposal will engage K-12 students in STEM activities through outreach programs. Undergraduates were part of analyzing data and graduate students have led several studies leading towards their dissertations. Three dissertations were supported in part from this project. A large eye tracking repository along with any methods, tools, and algorithms is generated from this research and published with each paper.

A growing number of education, software engineering and psychology researchers are using iTrace in related eye tracking studies.  Additionally, this same technology is directly generalizable to other types of environments such as spreadsheets, books, and legal documents that seek to study and understand human reading and navigation behavior. 

 


Last Modified: 12/18/2023
Modified by: Bonita Sharif
